image.altText: A barge at a port

items.synopsis: The British government says it's trying to "stop the boats", but one of its solutions — a giant, grey barge designed to house 500 asylum seekers — is proving controversial.

title.children: There's a floating 'recipe for disaster' off England's coast — it has links to Australia

image.altText: An illustration of a SARS-CoV-2 virus particle showing the protruding spike proteins on the virus's surface.

items.synopsis: A COVID-19 variant nicknamed "Eris" — after the Greek goddess of chaos, strife and discord — has been in the news after spreading overseas. But the variant has actually been in Australia for four months.

title.children: The newly famous 'goddess of chaos' variant is making headlines, but it's been lurking quietly for months

image.altText: A woman and child stand at a polling station.

items.synopsis: The Victorian government is facing mounting pressure to clean up the upper house voting system, which still uses group voting tickets despite every other Australian jurisdiction having dumped them.

title.children: Daniel Andrews urged to clean up Victoria's electoral system amid corruption risk concerns

image.altText: Wild Mushroom Death Cap

items.synopsis: The deaths of three Victorians after a Saturday lunch in the small town of Leongatha sent shock waves through the community, but also shone the spotlight on one of the most poisonous organisms on earth.

title.children: What happens when you eat a death cap mushroom?

image.altText: Anthony Albanese walking on a red dirt road surrounded by people in body paint carrying red flags

items.synopsis: Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander agencies, Voice to Parliament advocates and the prime minister have described a conspiracy theory on the length of the Uluru Statement from the Heart as a misinformation campaign to avoid debating the facts.

title.children: Voice to Parliament conspiracy theory an attempt to create 'misinformation and division'

image.altText: Graphic of Australian Bank logos on houses including Commonwealth, ANZ, Westpac, and National.

items.synopsis: The big banks were offering cashback deals and competitive rates to grab their share of the refinancing boom, but the trend has reversed as margins start to come under pressure, leaving some borrowers trapped between a mortgage cliff and a mortgage prison.

title.children: Why the honeymoon is over — banks pull back on fight for new borrowers

image.altText: People walk through the front door of a house, past a For Lease sign.

items.synopsis: About 30 per cent of Australians live in rental accommodation with growing numbers in seats that helped secure government for Labor. But the Greens want to win those votes and next week's National Cabinet will offer clues as to how determined Labor is to stop them, writes David Speers.

title.children: Next week holds an important moment for housing policy — and renters are gaining influence

image.altText: Actors.

items.synopsis: In India, the Modi government is accused of waging a war on Bollywood and using it for party propaganda.

title.children: 'You have to suck up or shut up': The clampdown on Bollywood's unforgivable sin

image.altText: A welcome sign that says Bright on the side of a road lined with trees with colourful yellow and red autumn leaves

items.synopsis: An avenue of scenic trees in Bright gains the support of the National Trust, as housing developments prove to be a major threat to urban trees.

title.children: National Trust calls for better protections for Bright's scenic trees from development

image.altText: Filipino marines standing on the deck of a rusty ship.

items.synopsis: For decades the Philippines have stationed a small contingent of marines on a rusting World War II warship that was deliberately run aground on a submerged reef in the South China Sea.

title.children: Why a dilapidated wreck has become a flashpoint for conflict between China and the Philippines

image.altText: A woman wearing glasses and a red jacket

items.synopsis: Legislation to establish the Parliamentary Workplace Support Service is the first major tranche of legislation to deal with the recommendations made by former Sex Discrimination Commissioner.

title.children: Legislation to establish parliament human resources agency tabled two years after sexual harassment review

image.altText: a man sitting behind a computer at a dining room table at home

items.synopsis: Larry took three jobs that were advertised and agreed upon as being work-from-home. Then the employers changed their minds.

title.children: Can employers advertise a job as work-from-home and then change their mind?

image.altText: A photo taken from the road of a huge orange blaze against the black smoke in the sky.

items.synopsis: Wildfires in Hawaii burn multiple structures and force evacuations from popular tourist areas, as rescuers pull a dozen people escaping smoke and flames from the ocean.

title.children: Six killed in Hawaii as wildfires force people to flee into ocean

image.altText: Close-up of Michael Buckland wearing a lab coat

items.synopsis: If pathologists start looking for CTE in the brains of domestic violence victims, will they find it? And what will it mean if they do?

title.children: The first female athlete with CTE was diagnosed in Australia — but there are roadblocks to testing domestic violence victims

image.altText: organe faced man with blonde hair

items.synopsis: Today's latest news, as it happens.

title.children: Twitter fined $350k for failing to hand over Trump data: The latest news with The Loop

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: Federal Health Minister Mark Butler has told ABC News Breakfast the government has given up on support from the Coalition but is talking to the cross bench about getting on board with its cheaper medicines measure. "We had fruitful discussions with the crossbench and the time for a decision is this morning," he says. "I think we've made the case about why this is a very sound policy around the world. "Pretty much every country we compare ourselves to, they allow 60 or 90-day scripts for these ongoing health conditions. It is supported by every patient group I can think of and every doctor's group." Butler says he does not agree with the coalition that it's been rushed. "I've read the motion that the Coalition is moving this morning and it doesn't seek to delay it by six months. The motion is to disallow the measure and it would go altogether," he says. He says he doesn't believe it will negatively impact the pharmacy sector. "I said first of all we would reinvest every single dollar the Commonwealth saves from this measure which is about $1.2 billion, every single dollar back into the pharmacy sector and we would talk to pharmacies and crossbenchers and others about the best way to invest that money."
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: Health Minister determined to get 60-day script plan through

props.alt: Close up of Mark Butler on news breakfast

children.content: (ABC News Breakfast)

Federal Health Minister Mark Butler has told ABC News Breakfast the government has given up on support from the Coalition but is talking to the cross bench about getting on board with its cheaper medicines measure.
"We had fruitful discussions with the crossbench and the time for a decision is this morning," he says.
"I think we've made the case about why this is a very sound policy around the world.

"Pretty much every country we compare ourselves to, they allow 60 or 90-day scripts for these ongoing health conditions. It is supported by every patient group I can think of and every doctor's group."
Butler says he does not agree with the coalition that it's been rushed.
"I've read the motion that the Coalition is moving this morning and it doesn't seek to delay it by six months. The motion is to disallow the measure and it would go altogether," he says.
He says he doesn't believe it will negatively impact the pharmacy sector.

"I said first of all we would reinvest every single dollar the Commonwealth saves from this measure which is about $1.2 billion, every single dollar back into the pharmacy sector and we would talk to pharmacies and crossbenchers and others about the best way to invest that money."

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: The government is rushing to save its plan to allow patients to buy two months' worth of medicine at pharmacies after the Opposition urged the Senate to tear it up. The move, which could see 6 million Australians able to collect two months' worth of medicine for the price of one, is set to take effect from September 1. Health Minister Mark Butler says it's one of the government's key cost-of-living measures. He said many Australians were having to make difficult choices between paying their rent, mortgages, putting food on the table and considering when they could afford the medication they need. The Pharmacy Guild, is heavily against the move with concerns it could mean community pharmacies go under. The Coalition says the government hasn't properly consulted the sector on the proposal. The opposition is set to move a disallowance motion in the Senate today, trying to use the upper house to block the proposal from occurring. This will happen unless the government agrees to renegotiate a funding agreement with the community pharmacy sector. ABC Political reporter Matt Doran told News Breakfast the debate would come down to the cross bench, after the Greens took Labor's side. This is the final day that such a parliamentary manoeuvre can be used before parliament breaks for three weeks.
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: Government set for Senate showdown on 60-day pharmacy scripts

props.alt: A close up of blister packs filled with tablets

children.content: (ABC News)
The government is rushing to save its plan to allow patients to
buy two months' worth of medicine at pharmacies
after the Opposition urged the Senate to tear it up.
The move, which could see 6 million Australians able to collect two months' worth of medicine for the price of one, is set to take effect from September 1.
Health Minister Mark Butler says it's one of the government's key cost-of-living measures.
He said many Australians were having to make difficult choices between paying their rent, mortgages, putting food on the table and considering when they could afford the medication they need.
The Pharmacy Guild,
is heavily against the move
with concerns it could mean community pharmacies go under.
The Coalition says the government hasn't properly consulted the sector on the proposal.
The opposition is set to move a disallowance motion in the Senate today, trying to use the upper house to block the proposal from occurring.
This will happen unless the government agrees to renegotiate a funding agreement with the community pharmacy sector.
ABC Political reporter Matt Doran told News Breakfast the debate would come down to the cross bench, after the Greens took Labor's side.
This is the final day that such a parliamentary manoeuvre can be used before parliament breaks for three weeks.

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: Sixto Rodriguez, who lived in obscurity as his music career flamed out early in the US only to find success in Australia and South Africa, has died at 81. His death was announced on the Sugarman.org website and confirmed by his granddaughter, Amanda Kennedy. He died following a short illness, according to his wife Konny Rodriguez, 72. Rodriguez's legacy took off after the singer and songwriter became the subject of the Oscar-winning documentary, Searching for Sugar Man. You can keep reading this story here:
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: Sixto Rodriguez, subject of searching for Sugar Man documentary, dead at 81

featuredLink.title: Rodriguez, subject of Searching for Sugar Man documentary, dies at 81

children.content: Sixto Rodriguez, who lived in obscurity as his music career flamed out early in the US only to find success in Australia and South Africa, has died at 81.
His death was announced on the Sugarman.org website and confirmed by his granddaughter, Amanda Kennedy.
He died following a short illness, according to his wife Konny Rodriguez, 72.
Rodriguez's legacy took off
after the singer and songwriter became the subject of the Oscar-winning documentary, Searching for Sugar Man.
You can keep reading this story here:

image.altText: a camera and silhouette of a woman beside it

items.synopsis: The Queensland mother is facing the prospect of having nowhere to live after raising concerns about security cameras inside their rental property. She became so concerned she and her children left the property.

title.children: Sandy was told cameras in her rental home were inactive. Then she saw one light up

image.altText: A stylised graphic of the ASX board with an up arrow.

items.synopsis: Wall Street indices fall overnight but the Australian share market looks set to buck the trend and rise in early trade.

title.children: Wall Street falls, Australian market set to defy downward lead

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: Good morning, Daniel Ziffer from the ABC business team here to kick off the day on our markets blog. The ASX 200 is set to lift (a little) despite losses on the key US indices. The Dow Jones was down -0.5% in trading, the broader S & P 500 -0.7% and the tech-focused Nasdaq -1.2%. The Sydney Futures Exchange sees the ASX 200 moderately higher when trading opens later this morning, up four points or +0.006% to 7,279 points. In March we found out that wages had lifted 3.7% in the year (well below inflation) through the Wage Price Index (WPI). That meant a cut to "real wages" — the income you have once you include what inflation has eroded from your purchasing power. There's new weekly payroll jobs figures out today, ahead of new WPI data on Tuesday. It'll give us a little look in to what's happening to pay packets …
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: ASX set to rise despite Wall Street losses

children.content: Good morning,
Daniel Ziffer from the ABC business team here to kick off the day on our markets blog.
The ASX 200 is set to lift (a little) despite losses on the key US indices.
The Dow Jones was down -0.5% in trading, the broader S
P 500 -0.7% and the tech-focused Nasdaq -1.2%.
The Sydney Futures Exchange sees the ASX 200 moderately higher when trading opens later this morning, up four points or +0.006% to 7,279 points.
In March we found out that wages had lifted 3.7% in the year (well below inflation) through the Wage Price Index (WPI).
That meant a cut to "real wages" — the income you have once you include what inflation has eroded from your purchasing power.
There's new weekly payroll jobs figures out today, ahead of
new WPI data on Tuesday. It'll give us a little look in to what's happening to pay packets …
